p: A very literal, or linear, implication of CLASH is that ceteris paribus, most aggression and violence should occur at the equator. But that is not supported by the evidence. Instead, there is considerably more aggression and violence in warm climates than in cold climates, yet there is somewhat less aggression and violence in hot climates than in warm climates—climates with average annual temperatures that exceed 24 °C (75.2 °F), which often are located inland and very close to the equator (see van de Vliert, 2013; van de Vliert & Daan, 2017). It is possible that population density matters? Not many humans, or even other animals (including parasites), can stand the heat, either physically or because there are simply limited opportunities for building a comfortable environment in which to live.
